bibl.title: Letter from A.S. von Mansfelde to Mabel H. Lazear, March 12, 1908

div1.p: Von Mansfelde writes that politics are involved in procuring passage of the pension bills.

div1.head: Letter from A.S. von Mansfelde to Mabel H. Lazear, March 12, 1908
div1.opener:
Dr. A. S. von Mansfelde, Ashland,
Chairman,
Dr. Chas O. Giesse, Holdrege,
Treasurer,
Stephen P. Morris, 408 City Hall, Omaha,
Secretary,
The Nebraska Association for the
Study and Prevention of Tuberculosis
EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE
Dr. S. R. Towne, Chm. Omaha,
Dr. E. J. C. Sward, Oakland,
Dr. W. F. Milroy, Omaha,
Mrs. Draper Smith, Omaha,
Dr. Henry B. Ward, Lincoln,
Dr. Chas. O. Giesse, Holdrege,
Stephen P. Morris, Omaha,
Ashland Nebr. March 12th 1908
Dear Mr. Lazear:
div1.p:
I could not write until today in sending
you the news of last night. The possible passage of the two
bills in the Senate will do much to help their passage in
The House. Mr Mead of The Merchants Ass. is doing most valuable
service in your and Mrs Carrolls behalf and he deserves a
line from you now; just a line of thanks - it will go far.

I can fully appreciate your feeling in regard to exposing your
private affairs, even to your bodily infirmities, to public gaze,
and yet one can be too exclusive even in this matter. Had
you told me earlier what is contained in your last letter,
(and that is not even sufficient) I had just had a letter from
Mr Thomas C. Lazear, which convinced me that it would not be
wise to send a statement of your present income East, I
immediately wrote Mr Lazear that I would with his permission
not send your affidavit to Washington, or New York, i.e. that I
would (conveniently) forget to send it; hence his telegram
to you not to send the papers, as I said, had you told
me earlier fully just what your means of livelihood are
now, I would not only not have advised the making out
a statement, but circumvented it, just as I finally did.
A few hundred dollars a year is a big sum, in the
sight of some of the impecunious Congressmen, for a woman
International Congress of Tuberculosis, Washington, D. C. Sept. 21 to Oct. 2, 1908
to receive a year, and we would have had a great deal of
trouble to convince them otherwise. Heroes and poets and
authors and their families must be starving or dead,
before you can arouse sympathy or justice for them.

Well, no harm has been done, and you are, in the
sight of them, as hard of as poor Mrs Carroll and
fortunately for you your bill will travel in the
same class with hers, Poor woman! She has already
any amount of trouble with her two oldest boys and
I have insisted that her friends in Washington take
them in hand.

My last letter from Mr Thomas C. Lazear is
a very nice one and I am anxious to meet him
sometime. He writes me that he is 77 years old
that is 15 years older than I am.

Generally speaking we have all reason
to be hopeful of ultimate success now. I will
write you again as soon as the bills pass the
Senate which, I trust, will be soon, thus giving
us a chance of disposing of the measures this
session of Congress.
div1.closer: Most sincerely your friend A. S. von Mansfelde.
